headline: Starbucks Cuts Prices in China Amid Sluggish Sales. What We Know.
summary: Starbucks  will lower prices for several drinks in China, the company announced on Monday, as it attempts to accelerate sluggish sales in its largest international market.  In a post on the Chinese social media platform Weixin,  Starbucks  said it would slash prices by an average of 5 yuan, or about 70 cents, on “non-coffee” Frappuccino, iced tea, and tea latte beverages to entice afternoon customers.  China is the coffee giant’s largest market outside the U.S., with more than 7,700 stores and $740 million in revenue last quarter.

headline: Starbucks Tinkers With Pricing To Hold Ground In China: Report
summary: Starbucks Corp. (NASDAQ:SBUX) will reportedly cut prices on select iced beverages in China by an average of 5 yuan (approximately 70 cents), the company announced on Monday. The move comes amid rising competition and more cautious consumer behavior in the world’s second-largest economy. According to Reuters, Starbucks shared in a post on its Weixin social media account that it will begin reducing prices on dozens of beverages, including non-coffee items and Frappuccinos, starting Tuesday. headline: Starbucks to lower prices in China as competition heats up
summary: BEIJING (Reuters) -Starbucks China will lower the prices of some of its iced drinks by an average of 5 yuan ($0.70) across the country, the company announced on Monday, as competition intensifies and consumers become more cautious about spending.  In a post on its Weixin social media account, the U.S. coffee chain said it would offer more "accessible" prices on dozens of its drinks, including non-coffee drinks and the Frappuccino, from Tuesday.  While China is Starbucks' second-largest market after the U.S., the coffee market is highly competitive and consumers have become more cautious about spending because of the slowing economy and concerns about job security.

While China is Starbucks' second-largest market after the U.S., the coffee market is highly competitive and consumers have become more cautious about spending because of the slowing economy and concerns about job security.
